Criminal / Police

Interacting with Federal Agents (ICE, FBI)

What to know about your rights when federal agents approach you

Your Rights

5 rights in this scenario

You do not have to answer questions from ICE, FBI, or other federal agents. Even if they claim they 'just want to talk,' you can remain silent. Anything you say can and will be used against you in immigration, criminal, or other proceedings. Clearly say 'I wish to remain silent' and stick to it.

Source: 5th Amendment - Protection Against Self-Incrimination

Federal agents need a judicial warrant signed by a judge to enter your home or workplace. An administrative warrant from their own agency is not enough and does not give them the right to enter. You can refuse entry and say 'I do not consent to entry.' An exception exists for exigent circumstances (imminent danger).

Source: 4th Amendment - Protection Against Unreasonable Searches, Payton v. New York

You have the right to request a lawyer before answering any questions from federal agents. If you say 'I want to speak to a lawyer,' agents must stop questioning. Do not answer follow-up questions after requesting counsel. Request an attorney in clear language, preferably in writing.

Source: 6th Amendment - Right to Counsel, Miranda Rights

If approached by federal agents, you can ask 'Am I free to go?' or 'Am I being detained?' If they say you're free to leave, calmly walk away. If they say you're being detained, you're not under arrest yet but they believe they have grounds to hold you. This is still a good time to ask for a lawyer and stop talking.

Source: 4th Amendment - Seizure Doctrine

Never sign anything a federal agent puts in front of you without understanding it completely and consulting a lawyer. This includes immigration forms, consent forms, or 'voluntary' statements. Agents may falsely claim a document is routine or harmless. If you cannot read English, request an interpreter. Never sign if uncertain.

üí° This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: 5th Amendment - Due Process; Right to Counsel
